Pre-Game Insights: USA will look to build on their success and cause another upset against favourites South Africa at North Sound, Antigua.
Coach Stuart Law told Al Jazeera after the USA’s qualification for the Super Eights was confirmed that 'We are not going to go down without a fight.'
USA vice captain Aaron Jones said his team are excited to rub shoulders with the biggest sides in the world.
South Africa captain Aiden Markram agreed that his side will have to 'be on their best game' against the co-hosts in Wednesday’s game.
Pitch condition: The Antigua pitch has produced a mix of low- and high-scoring matches, but conditions remain favourable for batting, and the pitch is vastly different from the one in New York, where all teams struggled to score.
There will still be some assistance for bowlers, especially wrist spinners and bowlers with high accuracy and control.
Weather forecast: The forecast for this week is cloudy and humid with negligible chances of rain.
Head-to-head: The teams have never met in any format of the game.
Form guide: While the USA lost their last completed match of the tournament against India, they would have gained confidence from their competitive display against the South Asian powerhouse.
South Africa are one of the four unbeaten sides in the tournament so far, but were nearly at the receiving end of a huge upset against Nepal in their last group match.
USA team news: The USA will welcome back their captain, Monank Patel, who missed the match against India, and left-arm spinner Nosthush Kenjige, who showed plenty of control with the ball against Pakistan.
South Africa team news: The Proteas may look to play two spinners and call up the wily Keshav Maharaj in place of one of their three pace bowlers.
